case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S.A.S. Marimuthu Nadar

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 427 and 428 of 1960 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 427 and 428 of 1960. Appeals from the judgment and order dated August 28, 1956, of the Madras High Court in case Referred No. 28 of 1953.

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order dated August 28, 1956 of Madras High Court in Referred No. 28 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated August 28, 1956, of the Madras High Court in case Referred No. 28 of 1953. N. Sanyal Additional Solicitor General of India, K. N. Rajagopal , Sastri, P. M. Sen and P. D. Menon, for the appellants.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on 1961 August 10 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961 August 10. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-These are two appeals against the judgment of the Madras High Court dated August 28, 1956.

facts.text: Question referred by Income-tax Appellate Tribunal Madras Bench.

anchor.surface_text: by which a composite question embracing two assessment years, referred by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal Madras Bench, B was answered against the Department.

facts.text: Referred question: Whether the assessee is entitled to earned income relief on the share income of the two minor sons for 1949-50 assessment year and on the share income of one minor son for 1950-51 assessment year included in the computation of the total income of assessee under section 16(3)(a)(ii) of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question, which was referred to the High Court, was as follows Whether the assessee, is entitled to earned income relief on the share income of the two minor, sons for 1949-50 assessment year and on the share income of one minor son for 1950-51 assessment year included in the computation of the total income of assessee under the provisions of section 16 3  a  ii  of the Income-tax Act

facts.text: S.A.S. Marimuthu Nadar was the manager of a Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, S.A.S. Marimuthu Nadar, was the manager of a Hindu undivided family. The family consisted of Marimuthu Nadar, his two major sons and two minor sons.

facts.text: Hindu undivided family consisted of Marimuthu Nadar, his two major sons and two minor sons.

anchor.surface_text: The family consisted of Marimuthu Nadar, his two major sons and two minor sons. On August 16, 1946, the family divided, and a firm came into existence.

facts.text: On August 16, 1946, the family divided and a firm came into existence.

anchor.surface_text: On August 16, 1946, the family divided, and a firm came into existence. Marimuthu Nadar and his two major sons took 4/16th share each and the two minor sons were admitted to the benefits of partnership to the extent of 2/16th share each.

facts.text: Marimuthu Nadar and his two major sons took 4/16th share each in the firm; two minor sons admitted to benefits of partnership to extent of 2/16th share each.

anchor.surface_text: Marimuthu Nadar and his two major sons took 4/16th share each and the two minor sons were admitted to the benefits of partnership to the extent of 2/16th share each. For the assessment year, 1949-50  the previous year ended on August 16, 1948   the share of profits of Marimuthu Nadar from the partnership was Rs. 9,812

facts.text: For assessment year 1949-50 (previous year ended August 16, 1948), share of profits of Marimuthu Nadar from partnership was Rs. 9,812.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year, 1949-50  the previous year ended on August 16, 1948   the share of profits of Marimuthu Nadar from the partnership was Rs. 9,812, while the share of profits of his two minor sons was Rs. 8,124 and Rs. 8,381.

facts.text: For AY 1949-50, share of profits of two minor sons Rs. 8,124 and Rs. 8,381.

anchor.surface_text: while the share of profits of his two minor sons was Rs. 8,124 and Rs. 8,381. The income of the minors was added to the total income of Marimuthu Nadar under s.16 3  a  ii  of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Income of minors added to total income of Marimuthu Nadar under s.16(3)(a)(ii) for AY 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: The income of the minors was added to the total income of Marimuthu Nadar under s.16 3  a  ii  of the Income-tax Act. Marimuthu Nadar was granted earned income relief only to the extent of his own individual share of the profits from the partnership.

facts.text: Earned income relief granted only on his own share for AY 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: Marimuthu Nadar was granted earned income relief only to the extent of his own individual share of the profits from the partnership. In the assessment year, 1950-51, the elder of the two minor sons had become major

facts.text: For AY 1950-51, elder minor son became major; only remaining minor son's share included.

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment year, 1950-51, the elder of the two minor sons had become major, and it was only the share of the remaining minor son which was included in the total income of Marimuthu Nadar.

facts.text: For AY 1950-51, Marimuthu Nadar's share of profits Rs. 12,344; minor son's Rs. 10,143.

anchor.surface_text: Marimuthu Nadars share of profits was Rs. 12,344 and that of his minor son, Rs. 10,143. Marimuthu Nadar appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and also to the appellate Tribunal but his appeals were unsuccessful.

facts.text: Earned income relief given only on his share for AY 1950-51, not on minor's share.

anchor.surface_text: In that year also, he was given earned income relief only on his share of the-profits but number on the share of the profits of the minor son, which wag included in his total income.

facts.text: Marimuthu Nadar appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Appellate Tribunal; appeals unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: Marimuthu Nadar appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and also to the appellate Tribunal but his appeals were unsuccessful. At the instance of Marimuthu Nadar, the Tribunal referred the above question to the High Court for its decision.

facts.text: At instance of Marimuthu Nadar, Tribunal referred question to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of Marimuthu Nadar, the Tribunal referred the above question to the High Court for its decision. The High Court answered the question in the affirmative and in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: High Court answered question in affirmative in favour of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in the affirmative and in favour of the assessee. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras, has therefore, appealed with a certificate under s.66 a  2  of the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras appealed with certificate under s.66A(2).

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras, has therefore, appealed with a certificate under s.66 a  2  of the Indian Income-tax Act. facts.text: No dispute about the amounts involved.

facts.text: No dispute about inclusion of minors' share of profits in total income of father.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Tribunal held no relief on minors' shares.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Tribunal held that in view of the definition of earned income in s. 2 6AA , only that portion of income was entitled to this relief which satisfied the companydition that it was earned by the person to whom it belonged before its inclusion in the total income of another

facts.text: High Court held entitled to relief on minors' shares as profits earned by father actively engaged.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that inasmuch as the profits were earned by Marimuthu Nadar working as a partner actively engaged in the companyduct of the business and the share of the minors was included in his total income, the definition justified the inclusion of the minors share in the amount, on which earned income relief companyld be claimed.

anchor.surface_text: s. 2 6AA , only that portion of income was entitled to this relief which satisfied the companydition that it was earned by the person to whom it belonged before its inclusion in the total income of another, and that in the case of an unregistered firm, the minor or the wife, as the case may be, must, as a partner, have been actively engaged in the companyduct of the business. The High Court held that inasmuch as the profits were earned by Marimuthu Nadar working as a partner actively engaged in the companyduct of the business and the share of the minors was included in his total income, the definition justified the inclusion of the minors share in the amount, on which earned income relief companyld be claimed. arguments.claim: Earned income relief can only be granted to the father in respect of his own individual share of profits and not in respect of the share of the minor or minors

anchor.surface_text: The contention, however, is that earned income relief can only be granted to the father in respect of his own individual share of profits and not in respect of the share of the minor or minors, as held by the High Court.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e of it. The companydition that the assessee must have worked actively as a partner is thus applicable also to the latter part of the definition. In o

arguments.court_reasoning: Section applies conditions to assessee who must be active partner; father's activity qualifies minors' included income

arguments.claim: In view of s.2(6AA), only income earned by the person to whom it belonged (minor) before inclusion qualifies for relief, and minor must have been actively engaged in conduct of business

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Tribunal held that in view of the definition of earned income in s. 2 6AA , only that portion of income was entitled to this relief which satisfied the condition that it was earned by the person to whom it belonged before its inclusion in the total income of another, and that in the case of an unregistered firm, the minor or the wife, as the case may be, must, as a partner, have been actively engaged in the conduct of the business before earned income relief would be admissible.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e of it. The companydition that the assessee must have worked actively as a partner is thus applicable also to the latter part of the definition. In o

arguments.court_reasoning: Conditions of active engagement apply to assessee (father), not minor; minor cannot be active partner

arguments.claim: Profits earned by assessee-father actively engaged as partner qualify minors' shares for earned income relief when included in his total income

arguments.claim: Such income must be earned by the person who receives it first (minor or wife) and actively by them to qualify for relief in father's hands

anchor.surface_text: According to the Department, such income must be earned income., and earned by the person who receives it in the first instance and not by the person in whose total income it is included by the Act. In other words to get the benefit, the income must be earned actively by the minor or the wife, before it can qualify for the earned income relief in the hands of the father or the husband, as the case may be.

arguments.court_reasoning: Impossible for minor to actively engage as partner; section's conditions attach to assessee; favors common scenario of active father

arguments.claim: So long as father or husband actively worked as partner, minor's or wife's income qualifies for relief even if initially theirs

anchor.surface_text: The case of the other side is that so long as the father or the husband has worked actively as a partner, the income would be entitled to the relief, even though it was initially the income of the minor son or the wife.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: can be taken into account in a taxing Act  in giving earned income relief to a person who has to pay tax on income which belongs to another but which

arguments.court_reasoning: Conditions of s.2(6AA) apply to assessee; active partner status of father satisfies for included income

arguments.claim: Reading 'such' as referring only to 'any income of an assessee' in opening is inadmissible as it makes no sense

anchor.surface_text: The words of the last paragraph of the section are and includes any such income, and the question is what income is indicated by the word such. Three readings of the section were considered at the hearing but one of them must be rejected as clearly not admissible. That reading is to take such back to the words any income of an assessee in the opening part of the definition.

arguments.claim: 'Such income' means earned income per earlier definition, with conditions (assessee individual/unreg firm; assessee active in business) applying to assessee even for included income

anchor.surface_text: The words such income refer, as we have said, not to the words any income of an assessee in the earlier part but to the whole definition of earned income given by the Act, before it says what is to be included in it. In other words, by such income is meant, earned income determined in the same manner in which that income is to be determined under the earlier part of the definition.

arguments.claim: General intention of section is to grant relief on included income of minor/wife where assessee (husband/father) pays tax; framed for common cases of active fathers/husbands, not rare active minors/wives

anchor.surface_text: Now, the general intention of the section is to give relief in cases where the income of the minor child or the wife is included in the total income of the husband who has to pay income-tax on the consolidated amount. Cases of wives and minors actively engaged in the conduct of a business are very few indeed, whereas cases of fathers and husbands actively engaged in the conduct of the business while their minor children or wives... are very numerous and of common and natural occurrence.

arguments.claim: Equitable to grant relief to assessee who earned the income though belonging to another

anchor.surface_text: There is also equity if equitable considerations can be taken into account in a taxing Act in giving earned income relief to a person who has to pay tax on income which belongs to another but which he has himself earned.

arguments.qualifiers: if equitable considerations can be taken into account in a taxing Act

arguments.claim: Section enacts inclusion of income earned by assessee (active partner) even if another's; 'where the assessee is a partner' applies to latter part; no violence to language

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the section can only be read as enacting that for purposes of earned income relief, such income will be included which, though it is the income of another person, has been earned by the assessee, or, in the case of a firm, where the assessee is a partner, by his being actively engaged as partner in the conduct of the business. the words where the assessee is a partner must be given effect to, even when the income of the minor or the wife is considered under the latter part, and they also point to the same conclusion. In reading the definition in this way, no violence is done to the language of it.
In our opinion, the High Court was right in the answer which it gave.

holdings.text: The High Court was right; the assessee is entitled to earned income relief on the share income of the minor sons included in his total income under section 16(3)(a)(ii) of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was right in the answer which it gave.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 2(6AA) includes income of another (minor) in assessee's earned income if assessee is partner actively engaged in business conduct; father's activity qualifies minors' shares.

holdings.text: The word 'such' in 'includes any such income' refers not to 'any income of an assessee' but to the whole preceding definition of earned income.

anchor.surface_text: The words of the last paragraph of the section are and includes any such income, and the question is what income is indicated by the word such. Three readings of the section were considered

holdings.reasoning_summary: First reading rejected as makes no sense; 'such' means earned income determined per earlier definitional criteria applied to assessee.

holdings.text: For included income to qualify as earned income under s.2(6AA), it is sufficient that the assessee (father) is a partner actively engaged in business conduct; minor need not be.

anchor.surface_text: The question is who must earn that income., or, in other words, in an unregistered firm, is it a condition precedent that the minor or the wife must be actively engaged in the conduct of the business., or is it sufficient if the father or the husband

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conditions attach to assessee; minor cannot actively partner; purposive intent favors common cases of active fathers paying tax on included income.

holdings.text: The definitional conditions under s.2(6AA) are satisfied in respect of the minors' share profits included in assessee's total income.

anchor.surface_text: The two conditions were obviously satisfied by Marimuthu Nadar in respect of his own share of the profits from the partnership. The question is whether they are satisfied in respect

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee Marimuthu Nadar satisfied conditions of being unregistered firm partner actively engaged, extending to included minors' shares per section's structure.

holdings.text: Section 2(6AA) enacts inclusion as earned income of another's income (minor/wife) if earned by assessee actively as partner; 'where the assessee is a partner' applies to inclusion clause.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the section can only be read as enacting that for purposes of earned income relief, such income will be included which, though it is the income of another person, has been earned by the assessee, or, in the case of a firm, where the assessee is a partner, by his being actively engaged as partner in the conduct of the business. the words where the assessee is a partner must be given effect to, even when the income of the minor or the wife is considered under the latter part, and they also point to the same conclusion. In reading the definition in this way, no violence is done to the language of it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gives effect to all words without violence; aligns with intent, equity, and common scenarios; conditions apply to assessee throughout.

holdings.text: General intention of s.2(6AA) is to grant earned income relief where assessee pays tax on included income of minor/wife from business.

anchor.surface_text: The general intention behind the section, in spite of its obscurity, is fairly clear. It is to give to an assessee, earned income relief in respect of the income of another person, included in his total income under the provisions of this Act. The only difficulty is about the conditions under which such relief is to be granted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Framed for numerous common cases of active fathers/husbands, not rare active minors/wives; equitable for assessee earning the income taxed.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was right in the answer which it gave.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court decision affirmed; assessee entitled to earned income relief on share income of minor sons included in his total income
